ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In taking this course, I was able to gain more insight into the structure of arguments, not only in my own work, but in reading the work of others. I was also able tot learn how to nuance my writing in order to make it mulitdimensional. I was able to gain a lot of skills throughout this course.

In the seminar, I learned how to think critically about the media--in particular, how the media selects and portrays the pain and how that links to power dynamics. I've also learned how to come up with a strong claim, use resources to conduct research, and write more effectively using the five elements of an essay. 

Most of all, I loved all the essays we were assigned to write. With each essay, I grew in terms of my knowledge, research skills, and communication skills.
Strengthened my writing.

- How to read and absorb academic texts
- How to structure an academic essay
- How to write in formal, academic English
- Pain and its entrance into politics

I learned about the difficulty of expressing pain and how that difficulty leads to the politicalization of pain for personal gain. Also learned how to craft a research paper for the first time from this course.
I learned how to structure and refine my papers and ideas more clearly.
I learned how to write a proper academic paper. It was extremely valuable to go through the steps of the writing process and learn the specific parts of each one.

I learned a lot about the incommunicability of pain and how difficult it truly is to understand the pain of another. This class was a great reminder to be empathetic and understanding toward others because our inability to feel another's pain can be truly divisive.

I learned how to compose college-level academic papers; how to effectively annotate and break apart the argument of source texts; how to find relevant sources for research; how to craft an original, research-based argument; how to ask for help when I need it/when I feel unclear on my progress.

I learned how to approach complex prompts and effectively organize a large amount of information. Additionally, I learned a lot about the writing process, and about the importance of continuing to make changes and revisions to your writing, even if these changes aren't what you initially may have had in mind.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that something overall that was difficult in this course was trying to unpack the change in terminology. A claim, problem, warrant, and motives were not the terms that I used for any fo my education previously, so getting comfortable with those terms was definitely challenging at times. The strengths of this course was definitely my professor. She cultivated an environment of growth and comfortability.

Strength 
- The course is very well structured and introduces college students to college-level writing very well. 
- The units are divided in such a way that students can practice in steps: close reading, synthesize two sources, research paper, and a video project. 
- The professor was amazing--Sara was so prepared and understanding all throughout the semester. 

Weakness 
- Sometimes, I felt like the discussions often deviated from the class topics.
- At first, I disliked having to learn the technical terms in an essay

Definitely targeted at people who have less of a background in academic writing. As someone coming from a high school that really focused on learning how to write, some of the content felt pretty basic. I think overall, though, there was plenty of helpful material.

Strengths: Forces students to read high levels texts at a relatively fast pace
Weaknesses: The focus on how to become a better writer could be strenghtened

Strengths: Sara! She is very great professor overall and she gives feedback that is clear and helps improve your writing. The readings are very insightful and makes you rethink what you know about pain. Also, the workload is manageable. No weaknesses

I personally wished that later in the course when we read a lot of different pieces about different ways pain and politics connect that we had dove deeper into one to two rather than looking more broadly in addition to our own research paper explorations.

The strengths of this course was that the content was very interesting and the professor guided us extremely well. The weakness would be the workload, because there were a lot of readings and papers due.

I do not have any weaknesses to list. This class was absolutely fantastic. Sara created an environment based on reflection, support, and open communication. I felt closer to my classmates in this class than all my others, felt more comfortable asking Sara for help, and felt more comfortable expressing my ideas and reflections in discussion. Likewise, Sara provided consistent, in-depth feedback on all of our assignments; with this, I felt I had the ability to improve with every new paper. Sara created such a wonderful environment for my first semester of college, and I think this class best equipped me for academic writing during the rest of my college career.

In terms of strengths, I think the prompts were very well-developed and really challenged the students intellectually. However, I think it would be helpful to add another essay or two into the curriculum. The essays we did taught me a lot, but more practice would have been helpful for me. Even though I already submitted my last essay for the course, I feel like there's still some things about my writing that need to be addressed and improved, and I feel like I could have finally reached that point of truly being confident with my writing if we had gotten more writing practice. The kind of assignments included in this course were very helpful, but I just think the workload needs to be increased a bit so that students can get as much as possible out of the class. However, considering writing is one of my stronger subjects, I do recognize that my opinion towards the difficulty of the course may differ from others'.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to other students. It helped me become a better writer and learn Yale's expectation of writing styles.

TAKE this class if you feel not as confident in writing research essays in college! All throughout your career in college, you will have to write research essays with minimal prompts, and Engl 114 will prepare you to have the skills to write those essays: from constructing your own claim to synthesizing your own research into your words. 
If you're interested in politics and different kinds of pain, Politics of Pain is also perfect for you.
Yes, it was helpful to my writing skills and honestly very easy to to well in.

I would, although I would recommend them making sure to chose a 114 course with topic they are really interested in. I would say the emphasis in the course is on the topic being covered and not on actual writing.

YES!!! I would definitely recommend this course to another student! It's the best class I've taken so far at Yale. I think everyone should take this course, regardless of your major, since you will learn so much and have really interesting discussion surrounding the readings. Sara is an amazing and organized professor so you will definitely enjoy!

I would definitely recommend this course. Sara is an excellent professor who provides valuable feedback for learning and she is extremely understanding. The course content is interesting and very applicable to other areas of learning. Although there is a lot of work, this class has taught be how to be a better writer.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because I enjoyed learning from Professor Misgen. She is a phenomenal professor and does a great job facilitating a healthy and safe classroom environment.

Absolutely!!! I cannot recommend this course and Sara Misgen enough! This class was definitely a highlight of my first semester, and I hope it can be for an incoming first-year too. When I came to Yale, I had a really hard time accepting that I belong here; Sara made sure that feeling did not last. She asked us from day 1 to reflect on what goals we are hoping to accomplish, and she helped us achieve them. She showed me that even at Yale, I can be a success and accomplish whatever I set my mind to! Sara helped me realize that I, too, have a success story here at Yale. Regarding the course specifically, it was a great way to be introduced to college writing. The course offers enough instruction and practice so that we come out feeling confident in our abilities to write college essays.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The professor was great, the content of the course was extremely interesting and applicable to everyday life, and the prompts we had to respond to were very thoughtful.
